answers.answer: Hi,How are you? Drop Foot syndrome may be attributed to a variety of factors, including many neurological diseases, paralysis of muscles, injuries to the legs or hips, drug toxicity, post-surgical infections, diabetes and tumors of the brain or spinal cord. Understanding the specific cause may help with determining the treatment options for this condition. Nerve stimulation or surgery have also  been used in the past. If rehab did not help, you may benefit from further evaluation and second opinion from other doctors. Take care and do keep us posted.

question: I had alot of complications after stomach surgery last year.  Was in a coma for 3 months and developed drop-foot syndrome.  I can no longer walk due to its severity.  I live in Alabama and was a healthy, active 48 year old female before my stomach problems.  I suspect the foot drop was due to lack of range of motion during my coma.  I had 7 months of rehab with no luck.  Tendons have too much constricture.  I can't find good information on the internet regarding this problem.  My feet won't go flat, they're on tip-toes and stuck in that position.  I can't walk at all.  Can someone please help me with information, treatments (surgery options since rehab didn't work), and recovery time?
title: Orthopaedics
